title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
There are two core aims of the hackathon we would like you to achieve:

Explore different tools and resources for conducting a range of common analytical tasks.
Write a functional script that applies one or more analyses to their own data and generates a report or dashboard to visualise the outputs.

title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
There are two core aims of the hackathon we would like you to achieve:

Explore different tools and resources for conducting a range of common analytical tasks.
Write a functional script that applies one or more analyses to their own data and generates a report or dashboard to visualise the outputs.

title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
Structure
You will be grouped by the analytical tasks you are interested in and work through them together with support from the facilitators. During these sessions, you will apply the analyses to your own data and incorporate the analysis into your final report/dashboard script. Depending on your technical level, you may complete multiple tasks over different sessions and therefore change groups.

title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
Tasks
The analytical tasks you can choose from are:

Reading, cleaning and validating epidemiological data
Generating automated situation reports with dynamic figures and tables
Making an interactive epi dashboard using epishiny
Visualising transmission chains using epicontacts
Getting epidemiological parameters from your data or the literature
Estimating the basic & effective reproduction number
Nowcasting epidemiological data
Forecasting cases and deaths
Estimating disease severity
Simulating disease transmission

Each task has its own dedicated page with resources and guidance. Click on any task above to explore it.

title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
Getting Started

Install R and RStudio: Visit the Setup & Installation page for installation instructions and required packages.
Download example datasets: Visit the Data section to download the datasets you’ll need.
Explore tasks: Navigate to the Tasks menu to find the analytical task(s) you’re interested in.
Join your group: Work through the materials with support from facilitators.

title: Analytics Workshop Hackathon
text:
Additional Resources

Recommended refresher on basic R literacy by AppliedEpi

title: Task 1: Reading, cleaning and validating epidemiological data
text: This task covers the basics of reading, cleaning, validating and shaping basic epidemiological data. You will learn how to import data from various sources, clean messy datasets, validate data quality, and prepare data for epidemiological analysis.

Import epidemiological data from various file formats
Clean and standardize data structures
Validate data quality and completeness

title: Setup & Installation
text:
Quarto Installation
Quarto is a scientific and technical publishing system built on Pandoc. It allows you to create dynamic documents, reports, and dashboards with R, Python, and other languages.

Installation
Quarto can be installed in several ways:

Install via RStudio: If you’re using RStudio 2022.07 or later, Quarto is included automatically. Simply install or update RStudio to get Quarto.
Standalone Installation: Download and install Quarto from the Quarto website.
Via Package Manager: Follow the Quarto installation guide for your operating system.



Verify Installation
After installation, verify Quarto is working by opening a terminal/command prompt and running:
quarto --version
If Quarto is installed correctly, you should see the version number displayed.


Resources for Learning Quarto

Quarto Documentation: Comprehensive guide at quarto.org
Quarto Getting Started Guide: Step-by-step tutorial at Quarto Getting Started
Quarto for R Users: Specifically for R users at Quarto for R
Epidemiologist R Handbook - Reports: Learn about creating reports with R Markdown and Quarto in the Reports section

title: Setup & Installation
text:
Required R Packages
Install the required R packages using the following code in your R console:
# Install packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")

pacman::p_load(
  # Add required package names here
  # This section should be populated with the actual required packages
)

About pacman
The pacman package simplifies package management in R by combining the functionality of install.packages() and library() into a single function. If a package is not installed, it will install it automatically, then load it.

title: Setup & Installation
text:
Getting Help with R Basics
If you’re new to R or need a refresher, here are some recommended resources:

Epidemiologist R Handbook - R Basics: Comprehensive guide to R fundamentals for epidemiologists. Start with the R Basics chapter.
AppliedEpi Tutorials: Recommended refresher on basic R literacy: AppliedEpi Tutorials
Epiverse Tutorials: Beginner, intermediate, and advanced tutorials for epidemiological analysis with R.

title: Setup & Installation
text:
Next Steps
Once you have R and RStudio installed:

Visit the Data section to download example datasets.
Explore the Tasks menu to find the analytical task(s) you’re interested in.
Join your assigned group and start working through the materials with facilitator support.

title: Task 10: Simulating disease transmission
text: This task covers simulating disease spread using mathematical models. You will learn how to generate disease trajectories, set up model parameters, and account for uncertainty in model simulations.

Learning Objectives

title: Task 2: Generating automated situation reports
section: Step-by-Step Instructions: Creating a Basic Epidemiological Report in Quarto
text:
Step-by-Step Instructions: Creating a Basic Epidemiological Report in Quarto
This tutorial will guide you through creating a basic epidemiological report using Quarto. You’ll generate an HTML report with an incidence curve, case fatality ratio (CFR), and an interactive summary table.

Step 1: Set Up Your Project Folder Structure
Before starting, it’s important to organize your files properly. Let’s create a clear folder structure:

Create a project folder on your computer called situation_report.
Within that folder, create the following subfolders:

data/ - for storing your datasets
scripts/ - for storing R scripts (optional)
outputs/ - for storing generated reports and figures




Step 2: Download the Linelist Dataset

Navigate to the Data page on this website.
Click the download button for linelist.csv.
Save the file to your data/ folder that you created in Step 1.
The file path should be: data/linelist.csv (relative to where your Quarto document is saved).



Step 3: Create a New Quarto Document

Open RStudio.
Go to File → New File → Quarto Document.
Choose HTML as the output format.
Give your document a title (e.g., “Epidemiological Situation Report”).
Click Create.
Save the document in your project folder (e.g., situation_report.qmd).



Step 4: Set Up the YAML Header
At the top of your Quarto document, ensure your YAML header looks like this:
---
title: "Epidemiological Situation Report"
format: html
editor: visual
---


Step 5: Install and Load Required Packages
In the first code chunk of your document, install and load the required packages:

# Install pacman if needed
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")

Loading required package: pacman

# Load required packages
pacman::p_load(
  rio,        # For importing data
  tidyverse,  # For data manipulation and visualization
  DT,         # For interactive tables
  lubridate   # For date handling
)



Step 6: Import the Data
Create a new code chunk to import the linelist data. Since you’ve saved it in the data/ folder, we use a relative path:

# Import the linelist data from your local data folder
linelist <- rio::import("data/linelist.csv")

# View the first few rows
head(linelist)









Step 7: Clean and Prepare the Data
Before creating visualizations, we need to ensure the date column is in the correct format:

# Convert date_of_onset to date format
linelist <- linelist |>
  mutate(date_of_onset = as.Date(date_of_onset))



Step 8: Create an Incidence Curve
Create a new section in your document and add a code chunk to create an incidence curve (epidemic curve) using date_of_onset:

# Create incidence curve
incidence_curve <- linelist |>
  ggplot(aes(x = date_of_onset)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 7, fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +
  labs(
    title = "Incidence Curve by Date of Onset",
    x = "Date of Onset",
    y = "Number of Cases"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14))

# Display the plot
print(incidence_curve)




Incidence Curve by Date of Onset






Step 9: Calculate Case Fatality Ratio (CFR)
Create a new section and calculate the CFR, making sure to exclude NA outcomes:

# Calculate CFR (excluding NA outcomes)
cfr_data <- linelist |>
  filter(!is.na(outcome)) |>
  summarise(
    total_cases = n(),
    deaths = sum(outcome == "Death", na.rm = TRUE),
    recovered = sum(outcome == "Recover", na.rm = TRUE),
    cfr = round((deaths / total_cases) * 100, 2)
  )

The estimated Case Fatality Ratio is 52.42%.


Step 10: Create an Interactive Summary Table by Hospital
Create a new section and generate an interactive summary table grouped by hospital using DT::datatable():

# Create summary table by hospital
# Group NA and "other" together
hospital_summary <- linelist |>
  mutate(
    hospital_grouped = case_when(
      is.na(hospital) | hospital == "other" ~ "Other/Unknown",
      TRUE ~ hospital
    )
  ) |>
  group_by(hospital_grouped) |>
  summarise(
    total_cases = n(),
    deaths = sum(outcome == "Death", na.rm = TRUE),
    recovered = sum(outcome == "Recover", na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  rename(hospital = hospital_grouped) |>
  mutate(
    cfr = round((deaths / (deaths + recovered)) * 100, 2),
    cfr = ifelse(is.na(cfr), 0, cfr)
  )

# Create interactive table
DT::datatable(
  hospital_summary,
  options = list(
    pageLength = -1,
    scrollX = TRUE,
    dom = 'rt',
    searching = FALSE,
    paging = FALSE,
    info = FALSE,
    ordering = FALSE
  ),
  caption = "Summary Statistics by Hospital",
  colnames = c(
    "Hospital" = "hospital",
    "Total Cases" = "total_cases",
    "Deaths" = "deaths",
    "Recovered" = "recovered",
    "CFR (%)" = "cfr"
  )
)







Step 11: Render Your Report

Click the Render button in RStudio (or press Ctrl+Shift+K / Cmd+Shift+K).
Quarto will process your document and generate an HTML file.
The HTML report will open automatically in your browser.

Note: The rendered HTML file will be saved in the same folder as your Quarto document, or you can specify a different output location in your YAML header.
